awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Science of Science Education: Resource Access, Conservation, and Cherokee Land-Based Education in Oklahoma
awd_abstract_narration:
The transmission of knowledge from one generation to the next is important in maintaining cultural practices as well as community resources.  Understanding the reasons for losing this knowledge is fundamental to explaining how cultures maintain practices and beliefs over generations.  The research supported by this award focuses on understanding the transmission of traditional cultural knowledge about the role of land and its use.  This research will investigate the barriers to the communication of this knowledge as well as seeking to understand how changes in language and decreasing access to and availability of resources represent substantial social and environmental challenges facing the Cherokee people.  How will the Cherokee people address these challenges and develop strategies for cultural revitalization and modify traditional practices of communicating cultural knowledge.  To answer these questions, anthropologist Dr. Clint R. Carroll of the University of Colorado-Boulder will investigate how Native American people mentally and physically navigate barriers to their land-based cultural knowledge and practices, how such approaches to social and environmental challenges may inform the broader society, and whether tribal environmental education in traditional and standard science can contribute to local cultural and ecological resiliency. 

The research will be carried out in five Oklahoma counties where Cherokees are the largest minority. The project has three phases. First, the PI will collaborate with the tribal biologist and a Cherokee group dedicated to the preservation of traditional ecological knowledge to devise modules for a special 3-year program focused on teaching the following: Western and Cherokee knowledge of regional plants, animals, and ecological processes; social science research methods, including ethnographic interviewing, participatory mapping, and GIS; Cherokee language; and traditional Cherokee medicine. The PI and his collaborators will then competitively select students to complete the program and gather data. The researcher and the students will survey rural households, conduct in-depth ethnographic interviews, and carry out participatory mapping to locate resource areas, record knowledge about those areas, and determine barriers to assessing them. The project will conclude with an assessment of the educational program, finalizing the resource maps, and analyzing the data to pinpoint the linkages between resource access, knowledge preservation, language revitalization, and land conservation. Findings from the research will document and contribute to social science theory of cultural resilience and adaptation to the environmental shifts and changing resource access accompanying climate change. Broader Impacts include training a future generation of Cherokee scientists, supporting tribal efforts to maintain language and traditional ecological knowledge, and documenting resources and language. All materials produced will be housed with the Cherokee Nation, in Oklahoma archives, and at the University of Colorado.

por.por_cntn:
The research supported by this award investigated the relationship between access to natural resources, the transmission of environmental knowledge, language preservation, and the maintenance of biodiversity in the Cherokee Nation (Oklahoma). Many Indigenous communities experience impeded access to lands on which to practice and teach traditional knowledge and language that are tied to the environment. This issue can negatively impact Indigenous peoples' ability to maintain their language and culture and take care of their homelands, decreasing both biological and cultural diversity worldwide. 

We explored how Cherokee people in Oklahoma are experiencing similar issues. The project sought to learn about Cherokee people's plant gathering activities in three rural communities to understand the obstacles they may encounter and how they react to them. We also asked if they have observed any changes in weather and human activity over the past ten years and if they think this may be impacting plants. Lastly, we asked about their views on land conservation and how increased access to gathering areas may affect individual and community health. We used short surveys and extended interviews to ask people about these issues. 

The research team included the PI and six student research assistants. These students also participated in an education program co-designed by Cherokee Elders to teach them the Cherokee language and traditional knowledge of the environment. The program also included lessons in Western science and natural resource management, taught by tribal scientists. The goal of the program was to give students an understanding of important issues using Indigenous and Western science, and to evaluate the effectiveness of this approach to training future leaders.  

We found that many Cherokee people in the communities we partnered with are experiencing access restrictions when they seek to gather plants. These issues mainly have to do with changing patterns in property ownership. Previous owners have moved or passed away and unfamiliar people are buying land and restricting access to local Cherokees. In many cases, the new landowners do not honor past agreements that Cherokees may have made with former landowners. In some cases, the new landowners are unfriendly to local Cherokee people. State wildlife refuges also restrict access to gathering places. People reported being harassed by game wardens when seeking to gather plants within refuge boundaries, even though gathering is not illegal there. 

People said that they respond to restrictions in different ways. Most go somewhere else if they know of other places to gather. Many said they will try to ask the landowner, but this can be difficult if the owner doesn't live near the property. Some people take risks and may trespass to get to the plants they need. Others simply go without, which negatively affects their connection to the land and the continuation of cultural practices.  

All participants agreed that plants should be protected so that Cherokees could continue to gather them sustainably. Most people were in favor of establishing special places to gather near their community. People said they had observed numerous changes in weather and human activity over the last ten years, including drought, flooding, and increased agriculture. Many people felt that having access to places for gathering would contribute to good individual and community health because this activity promotes culture, exercise, and natural foods and medicines. 

We began mapping activities with one community to better understand where they are experiencing obstacles and to help identify possible solutions. We plan to follow up with the other two communities to begin mapping projects there. After completing the mapping activities and additional follow up work, the PI will write a report to deliver to the Cherokee Nation Principal Chief's Office. The report will have recommendations for alleviating access restrictions based on the research findings. 

Key outcomes of the project were the design, coordination, and completion of the pilot education program. Students showed measurable improvements in environmental knowledge and Cherokee language. We also successfully partnered with three Cherokee communities to investigate the research questions. Community reception and response to the project was very positive. Broader impacts included training Native American scientists, supporting tribal efforts to maintain language and traditional knowledge, and documenting resources and language. 

This project contributes to anthropology by helping to understand how people respond to challenges that impact their cultural knowledge and practices. Better understanding how people adapt to social and environmental factors adds to knowledge about human culture and behavior. This is especially true among Indigenous peoples, whose cultures and languages are often deeply connected to place. In many cases, this connection to place informs ways that people interact with and take care of the land. Learning about these relationships and practices can help us understand ways to protect biological diversity and to promote cultural diversity. Many anthropologists agree that biological diversity and cultural diversity are interconnected. This project adds to knowledge about this connection.
